sentence: Self-tracking devices like AW are often used not only in personal, but also institutional contexts, for example as part of private insurance programs, or workplace wellness and employee monitoring schemes.

This case study deals with the ethical aspects of the Apple Watch (AW), a series of digital self-tracking devices developed by Apple which allow users to monitor their daily activity and receive personalized lifestyle recommendations and predictions.

Alongside third-party apps offered in the Apple App Store, AW allows users to keep track of a range of factors including the number of steps made on a given day, workout intensity, calories burned, mood fluctuations, and sleep patterns.

In addition to applications related to personal fitness and personal development, AW can also be used in medical contexts as its sensors collect information on metrics such as heart rate and oxygen saturation levels.

Self-tracking devices like AW are often used not only in personal, but also institutional contexts, for example as part of private insurance programs, or workplace wellness and employee monitoring schemes.

As discussed in deliverable 2.2, the promises and expectations associated with AW can be divided into three categories: advancement in tracking capabilities, impact on users, and appeal of the device.

According to the promises discussed in the first category, the development of new sensors and improvement of existing ones will allow users to collect more accurate and more granular information about themselves, while also lowering the overall price of the device due to miniaturization and advances in processing power.

According to the promises discussed in the first category, the development of new sensors and improvement of existing ones will allow users to collect more accurate and more granular information about themselves, while also lowering the overall price of the device due to miniaturization and advances in processing power.
These promises are closely connected to those in the second category, which discuss the potential positive impact on users.

At the same time, promises collected in the third category lead to belief that the increased ease of use and malleability of the device and its software will broaden the range of the viable users of AW, while also enabling them to better adapt the device to individual needs.

At the same time, promises collected in the third category lead to belief that the increased ease of use and malleability of the device and its software will broaden the range of the viable users of AW, while also enabling them to better adapt the device to individual needs.

At the same time, promises collected in the third category lead to belief that the increased ease of use and malleability of the device and its software will broaden the range of the viable users of AW, while also enabling them to better adapt the device to individual needs.

However, the AW can be seen as lacking from the standpoint of usability, since self-tracking involves a significant financial and time investment on the part of users and requires a degree of data literacy that might not be universally shared.
20.2.1	 Environmental harm
20.2.1	 Environmental harm

Like with many other big data technologies, the storage, transfer and processing of data generated through the AW requires vast amounts of electricity, so the use of the device, especially on a large scale, can have a long-term negative impact on the environment.

Like with many other big data technologies, the storage, transfer and processing of data generated through the AW requires vast amounts of electricity, so the use of the device, especially on a large scale, can have a long-term negative impact on the environment.

Like with many other big data technologies, the storage, transfer and processing of data generated through the AW requires vast amounts of electricity, so the use of the device, especially on a large scale, can have a long-term negative impact on the environment.

Like with many other big data technologies, the storage, transfer and processing of data generated through the AW requires vast amounts of electricity, so the use of the device, especially on a large scale, can have a long-term negative impact on the environment.

Moreover, the manufacturing of the device involves minerals that need to be extracted from earth (e.g., lithium) and the mining operations have been noted to be particularly harmful to the environment (see Crawford 2021 for a more detailed discussion of the environmental impact of AI and algorithmic technologies ).
Such large scale personalization techniques could have a negative impact on social relations, the interests of societal groups, social values and democratic life.
The collection and processing of data supplied by the AW transfers power to big corporations (most notably Apple, but also other companies offering AW apps in the Apple Store).

By using data to predict users’ behavior and offering personalized advertisements and lifestyle or health recommendations, companies are able to exert control over their users and (see Baker 2020; Gabriels and Coeckelbergh 2019).

If these companies are able to influence large groups of users in this manner, they might be able to at least partially steer social processes, values and decisions without adequate democratic oversight (e.g., by using the data to deliver targeted political advertising).

If these companies are able to influence large groups of users in this manner, they might be able to at least partially steer social processes, values and decisions without adequate democratic oversight (e.g., by using the data to deliver targeted political advertising).
Such large scale personalization techniques could have a negative impact on social relations, the interests of societal groups, social values and democratic life.
Such large scale personalization techniques could have a negative impact on social relations, the interests of societal groups, social values and democratic life.

This could, on the one hand, force some users to conform to ideals that might not best express their preferences and needs, and, on the other hand, limit the range of ways of life and perspectives recognized in the society as worthwhile and desirable.

As the AW can compound existing inequalities (both in economic terms and in terms of capabilities), increase the power of large companies over individual users and individualize responsibility over public goals such as health, it could be seen as a threat to democratic life (which I understand as characterized by social cooperation, communication and equal participation).
However, the sharing of data and bottom-up user initiatives surrounding the device might contribute to the development of friendship and solidarity and thus improve the quality of democratic life.
However, the sharing of data and bottom-up user initiatives surrounding the device might contribute to the development of friendship and solidarity and thus improve the quality of democratic life.
However, the sharing of data and bottom-up user initiatives surrounding the device might contribute to the development of friendship and solidarity and thus improve the quality of democratic life.
However, the sharing of data and bottom-up user initiatives surrounding the device might contribute to the development of friendship and solidarity and thus improve the quality of democratic life.
20.2.3	 Health and bodily harm

While direct bodily harm is unlikely to arise under a typical use-pattern of the AW, the device is quite likely to indirectly harm users’ health by inducing a false sense of security (see Piwek et al.

While direct bodily harm is unlikely to arise under a typical use-pattern of the AW, the device is quite likely to indirectly harm users’ health by inducing a false sense of security (see Piwek et al.

Users who depend on the AW for management of a disease (e.g., hypertension) and trust it to be reliable might fail to notice health- and life-threatening symptoms when the device malfunctions or when its data is not accurate enough.

Users who depend on the AW for management of a disease (e.g., hypertension) and trust it to be reliable might fail to notice health- and life-threatening symptoms when the device malfunctions or when its data is not accurate enough.

The obsessive examination of oneself encouraged by the AW can be seen as contributing to a form of digitally mediated hypochondria, or an excessive medicalization of everyday life (see Gabriels and Moerenhout 2018).
20.2.4	 Pain and suffering
20.2.5	 Psychological harm
20.2.5	 Psychological harm
20.3.2	 Autonomy
The personalized ads and recommendations discussed above can have an impact also on users’ choices.

Moreover, chilling effects might arguably limit the users’ autonomy to a similar degree as concerns about AW-facilitated surveillance could stop them from engaging in some activities (see Lanzing 2019).

With the help of AW data, such actors could manipulate or directly pressure AW users into specific behavior (e.g., insurance companies pressuring users to change their daily activity patterns or risk increased insurance prices).

With the help of AW data, such actors could manipulate or directly pressure AW users into specific behavior (e.g., insurance companies pressuring users to change their daily activity patterns or risk increased insurance prices).
The AW can limit user’s ability to think their own thoughts and form their own opinions in three interrelated ways.
The AW can limit user’s ability to think their own thoughts and form their own opinions in three interrelated ways.

With the help of self-tracking data, Apple and app developers can target specific users and feed them information that would manipulate them into desired ways of thinking and instill specific beliefs (e.g., about the relevance of a particular product in their lives).
First, personalized ads and recommendations can shape users’ thinking by suggesting content and mental associations to which the users might be the most susceptible (see Baker 2020, Lanzing 2019).

With the help of self-tracking data, Apple and app developers can target specific users and feed them information that would manipulate them into desired ways of thinking and instill specific beliefs (e.g., about the relevance of a particular product in their lives).

Third, the literature on devices similar to the AW extensively focuses on the phenomenon of datafication which can make users privilege numerical data generated through the AW over competing ways of gathering information (e.g., senses or testimony of others).

Proponents of this claim argue that as quantified data can be seen as more objective or accurate, even when that is not the case, users’ perspective and range of beliefs might be limited by the device (see Sharon 2017).
It is impossible to determine which parties could be held accountable for any of the harms arising with the use of the AW.

For example, in cases where a false reading supplied by the AW instills in a patient a false sense of security and convinces them not to consult their symptoms with a doctor, it is doubtful whether Apple could be held accountable for the unreliability of the AW sensors, or a third-party developer could be held accountable for the shortcomings of their algorithms.

For example, in cases where a false reading supplied by the AW instills in a patient a false sense of security and convinces them not to consult their symptoms with a doctor, it is doubtful whether Apple could be held accountable for the unreliability of the AW sensors, or a third-party developer could be held accountable for the shortcomings of their algorithms.

Moreover, such information would be probably impossible to understand for most users, as is the case with privacy policies and terms of service documents attached to the device (see Lanzing 2016; 2019).
Arguably, informed consent cannot be, in practice, guaranteed in the case of a device like the AW.
The algorithms and sensors which it uses are not transparent to the users and Apple protects the details of its device as their disclosure could benefit their business rivals.

This is particularly evident in healthcare, where AW-wearing patients could be expected to collect their data and monitor their symptoms to such an extent that they would assume some of the responsibilities previously allocated to healthcare professionals (e.g., routine checkups and tests might be replaced with an expectation to wear an AW and share data with a doctor, see Gabriels and Moerenhout 2018; Klugman et al.

In fact, this increased individual responsibility could also come to be seen as a moral obligation as users failing to use the device in a manner expected of them might be chastised for failing to fulfill their duty.

20.3.3	 Freedom

The AW does not pose a significant threat to freedom, although location data collected by the device could potentially be accessed and used by, e.g., authoritarian regimes to limit their citizens’ freedom of movement and freedom of assembly.

The AW does not pose a significant threat to freedom, although location data collected by the device could potentially be accessed and used by, e.g., authoritarian regimes to limit their citizens’ freedom of movement and freedom of assembly.
20.3.4	 Human dignity
20.3.5	 Privacy
20.3.5	 Privacy
20.3.5.1	Information privacy:
As the AW is a data collection device, it forms a significant threat to users’ privacy.
Moreover, as Apple is an American company, its values related to privacy might not meet some expectations of users from different parts of the world, such as Europe.
While Apple is required to comply with the GDPR, lax enforcement of the directive by the Irish DPA is highly problematic in this context.
As the AW is a data collection device, it forms a significant threat to users’ privacy.

Arguably, the use of the AW is a conscious decision for most users (some might be required to use it by their employers or insurers), but that does not mean users are able to express their informed consent for the extensive data collection done by the AW (see section 5.3.2.4).
While Apple has robust data protection policies (at least in comparison with many of its competitors), this does not necessarily apply to third party developers offering AW apps.
While Apple is required to comply with the GDPR, lax enforcement of the directive by the Irish DPA is highly problematic in this context.
While Apple is required to comply with the GDPR, lax enforcement of the directive by the Irish DPA is highly problematic in this context.
20.3.5.2	Bodily privacy:

While threats to bodily privacy are not as significant as in the case of pictures or video, the AW and associated apps can collect data and make inferences about users’ body weight, fitness levels, body fat percentage, etc.

AW data can indirectly expose users’ bodies in ways that they might not be comfortable with, as a significant part of the data collected by the device contains references to some parameters of users’ bodies.

While threats to bodily privacy are not as significant as in the case of pictures or video, the AW and associated apps can collect data and make inferences about users’ body weight, fitness levels, body fat percentage, etc.

However, surveillance practices associated with the AW (e.g., the use of the device in a workplace) could disclose users’ health and bodily parameters to third parties, potentially against the wishes of the users.

However, surveillance practices associated with the AW (e.g., the use of the device in a workplace) could disclose users’ health and bodily parameters to third parties, potentially against the wishes of the users.
20.3.5.3	Relational privacy:
20.3.5.3	Relational privacy:

Consequently, the use of AW can be a threat to relational privacy and even give rise to a form of decentralized, bottom-up surveillance of other users, discussed in the literature as coveillance (see Lanzing 2016).

Data collected by the AW and associated apps can include references to other people (e.g., fertility data might include some information about the users’ sexual partners) and data is routinely shared between users, for example in the form of leaderboards.

Data collected by the AW and associated apps can include references to other people (e.g., fertility data might include some information about the users’ sexual partners) and data is routinely shared between users, for example in the form of leaderboards.

Data collected by the AW and associated apps can include references to other people (e.g., fertility data might include some information about the users’ sexual partners) and data is routinely shared between users, for example in the form of leaderboards.

Consequently, the use of AW can be a threat to relational privacy and even give rise to a form of decentralized, bottom-up surveillance of other users, discussed in the literature as coveillance (see Lanzing 2016).

The AW can be seen as threatening users’ right to property as the data generated by the device and its associated apps does not belong to users and is instead treated as the property of Apple and third-party app developers.

The AW can be seen as threatening users’ right to property as the data generated by the device and its associated apps does not belong to users and is instead treated as the property of Apple and third-party app developers.

The AW can be seen as threatening users’ right to property as the data generated by the device and its associated apps does not belong to users and is instead treated as the property of Apple and third-party app developers.
Consequently, users are not granted control over their personal data and are not seen as owed a share of the profits generated through the use and sale of their personal data.
Consequently, users are not granted control over their personal data and are not seen as owed a share of the profits generated through the use and sale of their personal data.
Intellectual property rights are not applicable in the context of personal data.
20.3.7.1	Right to engage in peaceful protest:
20.3.7.1	Right to engage in peaceful protest:
Location data supplied by the AW could be used by the police and intelligence agencies to surveil and threaten demonstrators.
Location data supplied by the AW could be used by the police and intelligence agencies to surveil and threaten demonstrators.

Moreover, this data could lead to chilling effects by making users of AW less likely to participate in protests (although, of course, they could always not wear their device in circumstances in which they might be afraid of surveillance).

20.3.7.5	Right to pursue happiness:

As already noted, AW privileges certain perspectives (e.g., young, male and able-bodied) and could affect the social valuation of particular ways of life and individual circumstances, thus indirectly impacting some people’s ability to live a good life.

As already noted, AW privileges certain perspectives (e.g., young, male and able-bodied) and could affect the social valuation of particular ways of life and individual circumstances, thus indirectly impacting some people’s ability to live a good life.
However, it could not actually deprive users from the right to pursue happiness in the strict sense.

20.4	Justice
The AW does not negatively impact users’ ability to live a life of normal length.
The AW does not negatively impact users’ ability to live a life of normal length.
The AW could be used in intimate context as a tool of surveillance and thus be a threat to bodily integrity.
For example, domestic abusers could force their partners and family members to wear the device to monitor their everyday movements.

The AW does not pose a significant threat to users’ ability to use their senses, but as noted in section 5.4.5., it could lead users to privileging quantified information produced by the device over the testimony of their senses.
By privileging some perspectives and visions of the good life over others, the AW could push the users to conform with specific conceptions of the good.
Arguably, some features of the AW, such as fitness tracking or social features (i.e., data sharing) could increase users’ enjoyment of recreational activities.

As noted in section 5.2.2. on social harm and 5.4.6. on power asymmetries, the data collected through AW and associated personalized advertising could increase political power wielded by technology companies and reduce citizens’ control over their political environment.

In terms of material control, users are unable to exert control over their data (which is instead owned by relevant technology companies, see sections 5.3.6., 5.4.4.1.)
20.4.2	Global justice:

The high financial cost of AW, alongside the digital literacy required for successful use makes it likely that the device will disproportionately benefit the citizens of wealthy countries who possess the financial, infrastructural, and hermeneutical means to take advantage of the AW.
20.4.3	Intergenerational justice:

Despite some of Apple’s attempts at increasing the ease of use and approachability of the device, the AW might be less appealing or more difficult to use by the elderly, thus contributing to technological exclusion.

Despite some of Apple’s attempts at increasing the ease of use and approachability of the device, the AW might be less appealing or more difficult to use by the elderly, thus contributing to technological exclusion.
20.4.4	Just distribution
The AW is problematic from a distributive justice standpoint.
Instead, all access to self-tracked data from the AW is mediated by Apple and third-party developers who determine what information will be presented to users and in what form.

Although the data collected through the device is a result of users’ activity (to the point that some scholars consider this activity to be digital labour, see Till 2014, Lupton 2016), they are not given full access to it and are not able to freely reap its benefits.

Although the data collected through the device is a result of users’ activity (to the point that some scholars consider this activity to be digital labour, see Till 2014, Lupton 2016), they are not given full access to it and are not able to freely reap its benefits.
Instead, all access to self-tracked data from the AW is mediated by Apple and third-party developers who determine what information will be presented to users and in what form.
Instead, all access to self-tracked data from the AW is mediated by Apple and third-party developers who determine what information will be presented to users and in what form.
Moreover, their ability to control how the data is stored and accessed is also limited.
In this sense, data and control over it, is not justly distributed as companies behind the AW receive a disproportionately greater share of it in comparison to the users.
In this sense, data and control over it, is not justly distributed as companies behind the AW receive a disproportionately greater share of it in comparison to the users.
Admittedly, sale of user data is not part of Apple’s business model, and, consequently, this distributive injustice is not as problematic as in the case of devices competing with the AW.
Similarly, users are not given a share of the profits generated with the help of the data they contribute.
Similarly, users are not given a share of the profits generated with the help of the data they contribute.

However, third party developers supplying apps through Apple’s App Store have varied data monetization practices and users downloading third party apps are likely to see some of their data sold to external partners.

However, third party developers supplying apps through Apple’s App Store have varied data monetization practices and users downloading third party apps are likely to see some of their data sold to external partners.
In such cases, they do not receive compensation for the data they supply.

As the use of the AW is associated with significant costs (the purchase cost of the device, and, for many users, an iPhone, since an Apple brand phone is required to make the Watch work), time investment and digital literacy.

Considering the power that the companies (Apple and third party developers) wield over user data, as well as a lack of strict consequences of mismanagement and lax security, this risk disproportionately affects the users in contrast to the companies.

While users have no real control over data management and security (especially when the data is stored in the cloud and not on their devices), they are more likely to endure the negative consequences of unathorized access and data leaks (such as identity theft or data assisted burglaries).

The necessity to operate a touchscreen, and to wear the device on one’s wrist might pose difficulties to some users.

Apple’s accessibility features diminish these concerns to some extent (e.g., by offering a zoom option or a voice-over), but they might not always improve disabled users’ experience with third party apps offered on the App Store.

Apple’s accessibility features diminish these concerns to some extent (e.g., by offering a zoom option or a voice-over), but they might not always improve disabled users’ experience with third party apps offered on the App Store.

Furthermore, specific apps offered through the App Store might endorse standards that cannot be met by some disabled users and they might fail to accommodate the needs of the disabled users in their recommendations and analytics.

Moreover, some sensors and algorithms used by self-tracking devices such as the AW have been demonstrated to be less accurate for female users due to non-representative training data sets and reflection of gender stereotypes in the design of the devices.

For example, wrist-worn tracking devices are less likely to capture accurate activity patterns when they are carried in a handbag or when the user is pushing a pram, as women are often more likely to do than men (Criado Perez 2020).

Moreover, some sensors and algorithms used by self-tracking devices such as the AW have been demonstrated to be less accurate for female users due to non-representative training data sets and reflection of gender stereotypes in the design of the devices.

For example, wrist-worn tracking devices are less likely to capture accurate activity patterns when they are carried in a handbag or when the user is pushing a pram, as women are often more likely to do than men (Criado Perez 2020).

Apple’s own website does mention that the device might be not accurate for users with wrist tattoos but does not list user’s race as complicating the readings (‘Get the most accurate measurements using your Apple Watch’).

Racial bias of algorithms has been already criticized in literature (Crawford 2021) and there are some reasons to suspect that the algorithms used in the AW (arguably, especially in third party apps whose developers might not be as committed to diversity as Apple) might not have been trained on data sets representative of the racial and ethnic diversity of users.

Racial bias of algorithms has been already criticized in literature (Crawford 2021) and there are some reasons to suspect that the algorithms used in the AW (arguably, especially in third party apps whose developers might not be as committed to diversity as Apple) might not have been trained on data sets representative of the racial and ethnic diversity of users.
However, the AW does not incorporate image and voice processing algorithms (although AW apps may do so), which makes it less likely to exhibit racial bias than other algorithmic-driven technologies.

For example, it has been noted that many sexuality-related tracking apps fail to recognize the needs of gay, bisexual and transsexual users and only reflect the needs and circumstances of straight users (e.g., by warning a lesbian user about potential pregnancy resulting from sex with her longtime partner, see Delano 2015).
The AW does not discriminate on the basis of sexual orientation, but this is not always the case with third-party apps offered on the App Store.

As already discussed, the underprivileged members of the society are more likely to have the AW used as a tool of surveillance against them, or as a coercive/punitive measure (e.g., to access social programs).
The the collection of data enabled by the AW, coupled with corporate control of this data, increases the power of private companies over individual users and entire social groups.
The the collection of data enabled by the AW, coupled with corporate control of this data, increases the power of private companies over individual users and entire social groups.
Moreover, the AW can become part of vital social services, such as healthcare, thus further increasing the influence of Apple and third party app developers.

Although section 5.4.4 notes issues related to discrimination of specific social groups through the AW, it has to be noted that Apple has expressed a commitment to social inclusion and attempts to develop features of the device that make it more viable and useful to underrepresented user groups.

Although section 5.4.4 notes issues related to discrimination of specific social groups through the AW, it has to be noted that Apple has expressed a commitment to social inclusion and attempts to develop features of the device that make it more viable and useful to underrepresented user groups.

As already discussed in other parts of the deliverable, the AW can have a negative impact on the healthcare system and lead to individualization of responsibility over aspects of life (i.e., health) traditionally safeguarded by social structures.

As already discussed in other parts of the deliverable, the AW can have a negative impact on the healthcare system and lead to individualization of responsibility over aspects of life (i.e., health) traditionally safeguarded by social structures.
As it can help users achieve some goals related to their physical activity, manage illness and improve habits (e.g., sleep patterns), it can have some positive influence on users’ life.

Despite concerns about the AW’s impact on users’ autonomy, the limited range of standards it supports, and the potential feelings of anxiety it can lead to, the device could be conducive to users’ happiness.

However, by individualizing the responsibility for health and potentially changing the relationship between patients and doctors (e.g., lowering the amount of time spent on face-to-face consultations, or substituting trust for detailed data), its overall impact can be negative, especially in the long run.

However, by individualizing the responsibility for health and potentially changing the relationship between patients and doctors (e.g., lowering the amount of time spent on face-to-face consultations, or substituting trust for detailed data), its overall impact can be negative, especially in the long run.
As a data collection device, the AW can be a viable way of generating new information and thus help users develop knowledge.

In some situations, the AW can provide users reasons for prudential judgments (i.e., data supplied from the device could be used to determine the right course of action), but it is doubtful whether it can help users develop wisdom.
Moreover, as the AW can limit users’ autonomy and narrow their perspective (e.g., through datafication), it could limit the users’ capacity to make prudential judgments.

In some situations, the AW can provide users reasons for prudential judgments (i.e., data supplied from the device could be used to determine the right course of action), but it is doubtful whether it can help users develop wisdom.

The AW could be helpful in developing many virtues, such as perspective (by pointing to important factors normally ignored by a given user), care (e.g., when used by a caregiver to monitor their ward and help them in problematic situations), or solidarity (e.g., by encouraging users to share their data for research purposes).

The AW could be helpful in developing many virtues, such as perspective (by pointing to important factors normally ignored by a given user), care (e.g., when used by a caregiver to monitor their ward and help them in problematic situations), or solidarity (e.g., by encouraging users to share their data for research purposes).

The AW could be helpful in developing many virtues, such as perspective (by pointing to important factors normally ignored by a given user), care (e.g., when used by a caregiver to monitor their ward and help them in problematic situations), or solidarity (e.g., by encouraging users to share their data for research purposes).
At the same time, some of the concerns surrounding the AW (e.g., loss of autonomy, negative feelings connected to the use of the device) can actively prohibit users from developing virtues.
In terms of intellectual virtues, self-tracking can have a negative impact on wholeheartedness, open-mindedness and humility.
In terms of intellectual virtues, self-tracking can have a negative impact on wholeheartedness, open-mindedness and humility.

Existing research shows that users can develop a sense of dependence on their self-tracking devices and defer some judgments to the technology (see Baker 2020), which could be interpreted as a loss in terms of wholeheartedness: users may become unable to fully engage with their epistemic activities without technological mediation.
Moreover, critics of self-tracking point to the phenomenon of datafication, that is, the privileging of quantified data over embodied, sensory means of gathering information (see Sharon 2017).

For example, Gabriels and Coeckelbergh (2019) point out that when users encounter others merely as data points on in-app leaderboards, they might interact with them in a superficial and instrumental way (e.g., as a reference point for comparisons), especially in the context of the individualistic values associated with the AW, as identified in deliverable 2.

For example, Gabriels and Coeckelbergh (2019) point out that when users encounter others merely as data points on in-app leaderboards, they might interact with them in a superficial and instrumental way (e.g., as a reference point for comparisons), especially in the context of the individualistic values associated with the AW, as identified in deliverable 2.

However, fixation on the optimization embedded in the AW and on the numerical scores produced by the device could be a deficiency of humility as users might be unable to fully appreciate the context in which the data is produced (i.e., by ignoring other, non-quantified features of phenomena) and they might overlook about limited, reductive nature of quantified data.

The sharing of data enabled by the AW could lead to contacts among users, could open users to new perspectives and could allow users to engage in shared projects, thus contributing to the formation of friendships (see Sharon 2017; Barta & Neff 2016).

At the same time, Gabriels and Coeckelbergh (2019) argue that the contacts between users of self-tracking devices are often shallow and instrumental – for example, other users are only encountered as an impersonal data point on a leaderboard.
The AW is likely to have a negative impact on trust, as it can lead to the privileging of data over testimonies of other people and the privileging of data over one’s own sensory experiences.

The use of AW can help users conceptualize and achieve their goals (e.g., by translating the abstract goals of “getting fit” to a more concrete target of steps made per day or a running regimen), and to express their achievement to others through social features built into the device and its associated apps.

These include issues associated with just distribution of primary goods (i.e., profits and data, especially in comparison with the digital labor done by users), privacy and autonomy (especially information privacy and impact on decision making), power asymmetries, and impact on the perception of health and provision of vital services, such as healthcare.
